title: 112_hr1066
content: The Act titled "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2011" presumes certain diseases to be work-related causes of disability or death for federal employees in fire protection activities. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2011" amends the definition of an "employee in fire protection activities" to include individuals trained in fire suppression, with legal authority to engage in fire suppression, involved in fire prevention and response to emergencies. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2011" expands the definition of an "employee in fire protection activities" to include those involved in fire suppression and prevention. It establishes presumptions for diseases caused by employment in fire protection activities, which can be rebutted by evidence. The presumptions apply if the disease is diagnosed within 10 years of the last active date of employment in fire protection activities. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2011" expands the definition of an "employee in fire protection activities" to include those involved in fire suppression and prevention. It establishes presumptions for diseases caused by employment in fire protection activities, such as heart disease, lung disease, and various cancers, for employees with a minimum of 5 years in aggregate in this field. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2011" includes presumptions for diseases related to employment in fire protection activities, such as heart disease, lung disease, and various cancers like testicular, digestive system, colon, liver, skin, and lung cancer. It also covers any other cancer determined by the Secretary of Labor to be related to the hazards of the job, as well as uncommon infectious diseases like tuberculosis, hepatitis, and HIV. The "Federal Firefighters Fairness Act of 2011" covers diseases related to employment in fire protection activities, including heart disease, lung disease, various cancers, and uncommon infectious diseases determined by the Secretary of Labor. The National Institute of Occupational Safety and Health will examine the implementation of the Act, analyze injury claims, research on health risks, and make recommendations to Congress. The amendment made by this section applies to an injury first diagnosed or a death that occurs on or after the date of enactment of this Act.
